topic_seeds.description: Feeling overwhelmed by work demands and deadlines (relatively straightforward)

exchanges.user:
yeah so work has been pretty rough lately. like i know everyone says their job is stressful but idk this feels different. got this big project deadline coming up and my manager keeps adding stuff to it even though we're already underwater. 

also been having trouble sleeping. some nights i'm just lying there at 3am thinking about all the things that could go wrong. then i'm exhausted the next day and everything feels worse.

anyway. i trust you so figured i'd reach out. not really sure what im looking for but something needs to change i think.
exchanges.assistant:
**Work stress and the deadline:**  
That sounds legitimately overwhelming—not just "stressful job" territory, but the kind where the goalpost keeps moving while you're already running. When you're already underwater and someone keeps adding weight, it's hard to feel like you can ever catch up, no matter how hard you work. What kind of stuff is your manager adding? Is it related to the original project, or totally new scope?

**The 3am spiral:**  
That pattern—lying awake catastrophizing, then being exhausted, which makes everything feel worse—is a rough cycle. Your brain's trying to problem-solve at 3am when it's tired and your threat system is dialed up, so of course everything looks worse. Do you notice particular thoughts on repeat during those nights, or is it more of a general dread?

**"Something needs to change":**  
That voice saying something has to shift—what does it know? Like, when you hear yourself say that, what feels most urgent? Is it the workload itself, how your manager handles it, the sleep thing, or something else underneath all of this?

exchanges.user:
ugh ok so i tried to actually track what my manager's adding and it's mostly scope creep on the same project. like we had a feature list, now there's "nice to haves" that somehow became requirements. talked to him about it yesterday and he basically said "well the client wants it" which. ok. but that's his job to push back right? not mine to absorb unlimited work.

didn't sleep great last night either. better than the 3am thing but still woke up at like 5 and couldn't fall back asleep. my brain just immediately went to work mode. kinda frustrating bc i was actually trying to do the breathing thing you mentioned and it seemed to help at first but then i just gave up and checked slack.

the sleep is probably the bigger issue tbh. like even if the work stuff gets better the fact that i'm exhausted all the time makes everything feel impossible. don't even know what to do about that though.
exchanges.assistant:
**The scope creep conversation:**  
You're right—it *is* his job to manage client expectations and protect the team's capacity. "The client wants it" isn't a reason, it's an abdication. You naming that clearly tells me you already see the dynamic: he's passing his boundary-setting responsibility down to you, and you're left absorbing the overflow. That's not sustainable, and it's not fair. When you talked to him, did you get any sense he understood the impact on you and the timeline, or did it feel like he just deflected and moved on?

**Sleep attempt:**  
The breathing helped at first, then you gave up and checked Slack—that's actually useful information. The tool worked briefly, which means your body *can* down-regulate when you give it something to do. But at 5am, exhausted and already spinning about work, it's hard to sustain that focus when your brain's screaming "just check if something's on fire." The fact that you reached for Slack tells me part of you might feel like staying on top of work is the only way to manage the anxiety. Does that land?

One thing that might help: when you wake up early like that, your goal isn't to fall back asleep right away—it's to keep your body calm enough that rest is still happening, even if you're awake. Sometimes trying to force sleep makes the frustration worse. There's a technique called "rest, don't sleep"—if you wake up at 5am, instead of fighting it, you stay in bed, eyes closed, and just let your body be still. No phone, no Slack. You might not sleep, but you're still giving your nervous system a break. Worth trying next time?

**Sleep as the bigger issue:**  
You said the sleep might be the bigger problem, and I think you're onto something. Exhaustion makes everything harder—your tolerance for stress drops, small things feel catastrophic, and even good days feel bad. But here's the thing: the work stress and the sleep are feeding each other. The deadline anxiety keeps you wired at night, then the exhaustion makes the work feel more overwhelming, which amps the anxiety back up. Breaking that cycle might mean working on both ends at once—boundaries at work *and* sleep strategies—rather than waiting for one to fix the other. What feels more in your control right now: pushing back on the scope creep, or giving yourself better tools for when your brain fires up at 5am?

the sleep thing is definitely helping more than i expected. like i'm not sleeping great every night but at least some nights are better now. the rest-dont-sleep approach makes sense when you explain it like that. still waking up early though, just handling it better.

exchanges.assistant:
**The rest-don't-sleep thing working:**  
That's huge that it worked even once—waking up at 4:30, not checking Slack, staying still, and actually going back to sleep. That's breaking the pattern right where it usually spirals. Your body learned something: "I can wake up and it doesn't have to turn into a catastrophe." Not every night will go that way, but now you have proof it's possible. Keep trying it when you wake up early—the more you practice, the more automatic it becomes.

**The manager conversation backfiring:**  
Oof, the "team player" card. That's a classic deflection—reframing your boundary as disloyalty instead of addressing the actual problem you raised. You named something real (unsustainable workload), and instead of engaging with it, he made it about your attitude. That's frustrating because it shut down the conversation you were trying to have. And now you're in this weird limbo where you haven't talked since, which probably feels tense but also like... maybe you don't want to? When you think about talking to him again, what comes up—dread, avoidance, anger, or something else?

Here's the thing: you *were* being a team player by raising it. Teams don't function when people silently burn out. He just didn't want to hear it, and that says more about him than you.

**Anger showing up under the anxiety:**  
Yeah, that's completely normal—and actually healthy. Anxiety and anger are often layered: anxiety shows up first because it's safer (it blames yourself: "I can't handle this"), but anger is what happens when you realize the problem isn't you, it's the situation. You're pissed because your manager is failing at his job and making it your problem, and that's a reasonable thing to feel. The anger might feel uncomfortable because it's newer or less familiar than the anxiety, but it's giving you clarity. What does the anger want? Like, if you listened to that frustration, what would it tell you to do—set a harder boundary, look for other options, stop covering for him, something else?

also been thinking—and maybe this is weird—but i do this thing where i take responsibility for stuff that's not really my responsibility. with work, with my mom (she's been calling more, asking for stuff), with like everything. is that connected to the sleep thing or am i spiraling into something new?
exchanges.assistant:
**The realization about taking on extra work:**  
That's a really important insight—you've been proving yourself by overextending, then resenting him for not protecting you from yourself. And you're right: both things are true. He should be managing scope and protecting his team's capacity, *and* you've been making it easier for him to avoid that by absorbing the overflow without complaint. Recognizing that pattern is the first step to changing it. The tricky part now is: can you stop taking on extra work even when your brain screams "but what if he thinks you don't care"? That voice is loud, I bet.

**Real sleep at 6:30am:**  
That's a huge shift. Real sleep, waking up at a normal time—your body's starting to trust that nighttime doesn't have to be a battleground. The "let myself be tired instead of fighting it" thing you mentioned? That's exactly right. Fighting exhaustion amps up your nervous system, which makes sleep harder. Letting yourself be tired is actually giving your body permission to rest. Keep doing that.

**Avoiding the manager conversation:**  
You said "probably not great" like you're judging yourself for it, but honestly? Taking space after someone deflected your boundary with "team player" guilt is reasonable. You don't owe him a conversation when you're still figuring out how you feel and what you want to do. At some point you'll probably need to engage again—because avoiding forever gets unsustainable—but right now, focusing on your work and not taking on extra stuff is exactly where your energy should go. When that "what if he thinks you don't care" voice shows up, what happens if you respond with: "Let him think that for now. I'm doing my job, and that's enough"?

**Taking responsibility for things that aren't your responsibility:**  
Not weird at all—and yeah, it's connected. The work thing, your mom calling and asking for stuff, the sleep anxiety, the people-pleasing—it's all the same pattern. You take on other people's problems (your manager's boundary-setting, your mom's needs, your own exhaustion) and treat them like your job to fix. That's exhausting, and it's part of why your body's been so wired. When you're responsible for everything, your nervous system never gets to fully relax. 

Here's a question: where did you learn that taking responsibility for other people's stuff was your job? Like, is this something you've always done, or is there a moment or relationship where it started?

exchanges.user:

exchanges.assistant:
**The realization about your mom:**  
That's a huge piece to land on—by high school you were managing her life while trying to be a teenager yourself. That's not a role you chose; it's a role you had to take because she couldn't (or wouldn't) handle her own responsibilities. And now you're doing the exact same thing with your manager: stepping in, absorbing what he should be managing, treating his failures as your problem to solve. The pattern makes so much sense now. It's not just people-pleasing—it's survival. You learned early that if you don't handle it, it won't get handled, and things will fall apart. That's a lot of weight for a kid to carry, and it's a lot of weight to still be carrying now.

**Saying no to your mom:**  
That "felt weird, like I was being mean" feeling? That's the old pattern pushing back. You weren't mean—you set a boundary. But when you've spent years being the person who fixes things, saying "you need to handle it" feels like abandonment, even when it's not. Her getting quiet and pouty is her discomfort with the boundary, not evidence that you did something wrong. She's used to you saying yes. You changing that is going to feel uncomfortable for both of you for a while, but that discomfort is the price of getting your energy back. How did you feel a few hours after the call, once the immediate guilt faded? 

One thing to watch for: she might escalate—call more, make bigger requests, guilt-trip harder—because the old pattern isn't working anymore. If that happens, it doesn't mean you're doing it wrong. It means the boundary is working, and she's testing it.

**Work boundary (sort of):**  
"I'd need to see the scope first" instead of auto-yes is real progress. You didn't cave immediately, and you didn't take responsibility for something before knowing what it actually is. His annoyance is his problem—he's annoyed because you're not making his life easier anymore by being the person who always says yes. That's good. You're breaking the pattern.

But here's the thing: "I'll need to see the scope first" buys you time, but it's not a no. What happens when you see the scope and it's too much? Will you feel pressure to say yes anyway because you "asked to see it" and now he's waiting on an answer? If the scope is genuinely too much on top of your current workload, what would it take for you to say: "I can't take this on without dropping something else—what's the priority?"

**Sleep quiet:**  
Your body not knowing what to do with the quiet after a week without 3am panic—that's your nervous system recalibrating. For so long, nighttime meant vigilance: catastrophizing, problem-solving, being on alert. Now there's space, and space feels unfamiliar. That's not a bad thing. It might feel weird or even a little empty for a bit, but your body's learning that nighttime can just be rest. Let it be weird. It won't stay weird forever.

exchanges.assistant:
**The work boundary:**  
"Ideally both" is such a non-answer—he wants you to solve his resource problem for him, and when you named reality ("that's not realistic"), he went cold instead of doing his actual job, which is prioritizing. You're right to hate the awkwardness, but here's what matters: you held the line. You didn't absorb the impossible, you didn't say yes to make him comfortable, and you didn't apologize for stating a fact. The coldness is his discomfort with not getting what he wants. That's on him to manage, not you to fix by caving. The awkwardness might linger for a bit, but you didn't fail here—you did exactly what you needed to do.

**Your mom escalating:**  
Three calls in two days, progressively pushier, ending with a co-sign request and an hour-long vent—this is exactly what I meant by "she might escalate." The old pattern (you say yes, she gets her needs met) stopped working, so she's turning up the volume to see if that gets you back in line. And it worked: you answered every call, you listened for an hour, you're back to absorbing her stuff. But here's the thing—you didn't fail at the boundary. You just learned how hard it is to hold one when someone you love is pushing against it.

"She's my mom, right? I can't just not answer." Let's sit with that for a second. What would happen if you didn't answer the third call in two days? Like, actually—what's the worst outcome you imagine? Because right now, the cost of answering every call is that you're drained, back in the caretaker role, and your sleep is suffering again. At some point, protecting your energy has to matter more than being available every single time she reaches out.

One thing you could try: let the call go to voicemail sometimes. Not every call, not as punishment, but as a way to create space between her need and your automatic response. If it's urgent, she'll leave a message. If it's not, she'll survive until you call back on your terms. You get to decide when you have the capacity to engage, rather than letting her decide for you. Does that feel possible, or does it feel like abandoning her?

**Sleep disruption:**  
The restless night after the boundary stress makes total sense—your nervous system's activated again. You hadn't "figured out" sleep in a permanent way; you'd just had a string of calmer nights because the stressors had eased up. Now the work tension and your mom's escalation are back in the mix, and your body's responding. This doesn't mean you've lost progress. It means sleep is connected to what's happening in your life, which it always will be. The tools still work (rest-don't-sleep, letting yourself be tired instead of fighting it)—you just have to use them again now that things are stirred up.

The pattern I'm seeing: you're practicing boundaries at work and they're holding (even though it's uncomfortable), but with your mom, the boundary collapsed under pressure. That's not failure—that's information. It tells you where the work needs to focus next. What feels harder about holding a boundary with her than with your manager?

exchanges.user:
been a few days and i've been thinking about what you asked—why is my mom harder than my manager. and honestly i think it's because with him i can just like, deal with the awkwardness. but with her it feels like i'm actually hurting her, you know? like she needs help and i'm saying no. that's different than him being annoyed that i won't take on extra work.

exchanges.assistant:
**The difference between your mom and your manager:**  
That distinction you made—"with him it's awkwardness, with her it feels like I'm hurting her"—that's the core of it. With your manager, you can tolerate his discomfort because you don't feel responsible for his emotions. But with your mom, saying no feels like harm because you've been the one keeping her afloat for so long. Her needing help and you saying no activates that old belief: "If I don't handle it, who will? And if no one does, it's my fault." That's not actually true, but it's what you learned early, and it runs deep.

**The conversation with her:**  
"I know you've always taken care of things, that's on me"—that's a huge moment. She took responsibility for the pattern instead of guilting you or deflecting. That's not nothing. And the fact that it made you emotional makes sense—you've probably been waiting a long time to hear her acknowledge what that role cost you. It doesn't undo the years of carrying her stuff, but it shifts something. She heard you. She didn't push back or escalate or make it about her feelings. She just… heard you.

The fact that you haven't heard from her since isn't rejection—it's her giving you the space you asked for. That's her respecting the boundary, even if it's uncomfortable for her. Let yourself have that space without feeling guilty for it.

**Work: the straight no:**  
Second time saying no was easier—that's exactly how it works. The first boundary is the hardest because you're breaking the pattern and your brain's screaming about all the catastrophic outcomes. The second time, you have evidence: "I said no before, he got cold, the world didn't end, and I survived the discomfort." So this time your body didn't fight you as hard. The silence from him might feel weird, but it's also possible he's finally accepted that you're not the person who auto-yes anymore. He's recalibrating too.

**Sleep back to mostly normal:**  
Your sleep's tracking with your stress, which makes sense—when boundaries hold and the pressure eases, your nervous system settles. You've got the tools now (rest-don't-sleep, letting yourself be tired), and you're using them when you need them. That's the goal: not perfect sleep every night, but knowing what to do when your body gets activated.

One thing I'm noticing across all of this—work, your mom, sleep—you're learning that boundaries don't have to be perfect to work. You can hold one, let another one slip, then come back and try again. That's not failure. That's how change actually happens.

exchanges.assistant:
**Your manager's apology:**  
That's a significant shift—he named what he did wrong ("team player" comment was unfair), acknowledged the pattern (you absorbing too much), and is supposedly doing something structural about it (talking to his boss about hiring or timelines). Whether anything actually changes remains to be seen, but the fact that he came to you instead of waiting for you to bring it up again? That matters. It means your boundaries landed, even if it took him a while to sit with the discomfort and realize he needed to do something different.

And yeah, you were probably holding onto resentment—that makes total sense. He dismissed your concern, made you feel disloyal for naming reality, then went cold when you didn't absorb the impossible. That hurt, and some part of you was braced for more of the same. The apology disrupted that bracing. It's disorienting when someone surprises you by actually showing up and taking responsibility, especially when you'd already written them off as unlikely to change.

**Your mom and dinner:**  
Texting normal stuff, dinner next week—that's what a boundary makes room for. When you're not constantly in crisis-manager mode, there's space for an actual relationship. And that "what if she asks you to do something" thought showing up with less power behind it? That's because you know something now that you didn't before: saying no is an option, and you can survive her reaction to it. The fear loses its grip when you have proof you can handle the thing you were afraid of. That's not weird at all—that's exactly how boundaries create safety.

**Sleep solid:**  
Woke up one night, used the rest thing, fell back asleep—your body's got the rhythm now. It knows what to do when it wakes up, and it trusts that you're not going to fight it or catastrophize. That's huge. Sleep feeling normal again isn't just about the techniques—it's about your life being less activating. Work pressure eased, your mom backed off, you're holding boundaries that used to collapse. Your nervous system's responding to all of that.

exchanges.assistant:
**Dinner with your mom:**  
That sounds like exactly what a healthier relationship can look like—just... normal. Eating, talking about her garden, your work without you jumping in to fix things. No crisis, no asks, no emotional labor beyond just being present. The fact that it felt surreal makes sense—this isn't what you're used to with her. But surreal doesn't mean bad. It means the old pattern (you managing her life while trying to connect) has shifted enough that there's room for something lighter.

**Work spiral after the apology:**  
Yeah, nothing's actually changed yet. He apologized, said he'd talk to his boss, and then... silence. No job posting, no timeline, no follow-up. So now you're left wondering: was the apology real, or was it just smoothing things over so you'd stop pushing back? That uncertainty is activating because you can't tell if you're being heard or managed. Both are possible. He might genuinely mean it and structural change just takes time, or he might've said what he needed to say to ease the tension without actually intending to do anything. You won't know which until more time passes, and that ambiguity is hard to sit with.

Here's the thing though: whether he follows through or not doesn't change what you did. You set a boundary, you held it even when it was uncomfortable, and you're not taking on the impossible anymore. His apology doesn't undo that, and his inaction doesn't undo it either. If nothing changes structurally and the workload stays unsustainable, you'll have another decision to make—but that decision will be about what *you* do next (stay and keep holding boundaries, escalate it yourself, start looking elsewhere), not about whether you're "allowed" to have limits.

The "should I follow up or does that make me look needy" thought—let's look at that. What's the fear under "looking needy"? Is it that he'll see you as high-maintenance and it'll hurt your standing? Or is it more that following up feels like you're chasing validation that he actually meant what he said? Because if it's the second thing, that's the old pattern talking: seeking reassurance that you're valued instead of trusting that your boundary was reasonable regardless of his response.

One option: you could follow up, but frame it as information-gathering, not validation-seeking. Something like: "You mentioned talking to your boss about hiring or restructuring—any update on that?" That's a neutral check-in on something he said he'd do, not you asking for permission or approval. But you could also just... not follow up, and see what he does. If he meant it, he'll update you. If he didn't, the silence will tell you that too. What feels more true to where you are right now?

**Sleep restless again:**  
The work uncertainty stirred things back up, and your sleep responded—that's the same pattern as before. When your nervous system's activated (Am I being managed? Did I misjudge this? Should I follow up?), your body stays a little wired even when you're trying to rest. The fact that it's restless and not the old 3am catastrophizing spiral means you're not back where you started—you're just activated, not fully dysregulated. The rest-don't-sleep thing still works here when you need it.

**"It still feels fragile":**  
Yeah, because it is. You've made real changes—boundaries with your mom, boundaries at work, better sleep most nights—but those changes are new, and new things feel unstable for a while. You're not imagining the fragility. The difference between "better" and "solid" is time and repetition. The more you practice holding boundaries and surviving the discomfort, the less fragile it'll feel. But right now, you're in the in-between: you know the old way doesn't work, and the new way isn't automatic yet. That's uncomfortable, but it's also where growth happens.

Some days will feel wobbly. That doesn't mean you're going backward—it means you're still learning how to trust that the changes will hold.
